claim: In the past decade, K-12 funding has grown six times faster than the rate of enrollment.
The health care bill has "six years of costs against 10 years of tax revenue."
A telephone company will no longer have to provide landline service to customers if there is an alternative provider, including wireless.
A telecom bill could keep the State Corporation Commission from getting rate-of-return information from electric utilities.
Gov. Bob McDonnell in 2010 "did not even create enough jobs to keep pace with population growth" in Virginia.
qoute: A blend of truth and misleading figures

claim: "We’ve now gained private sector jobs 12 months in a row."
The stimulus bill "promised to keep unemployment under 8%."
qoute: Trotting out a tired, old claim

claim: "The American people have endured 21 consecutive months of 9% or higher unemployment [and] 2.6 million jobs have been lost," since the stimulus bill was signed.
qoute: New job growth slow to match earlier losses

claim: Under former President George W. Bush’s administration "while the population in that period grew by 10 percent, the number of jobs in the nation grew by 1 percent."
qoute: Lots of new people, fewer new jobs

claim: Tim Kaine wants to thwart "right-to-work reform measures in Midwest battleground states."
The House of Delegates budget bill "cuts $50 million from education."
qoute: In the end, less money for classrooms

claim: Road construction bids "are coming in at the lowest in the modern era."
qoute: Has no data to prove his claim

claim: The United states is "borrowing more than 40 cents of every dollar we spend."
qoute: We graded this in red ink

claim: "Senator Webb was a reliable vote for President Obama and Senator Harry Reid."
qoute: Webb backed party on key bills

claim: The war in Iraq was a major factor in blowing "the top off the price of oil."
qoute: Rising global demand played far more improtant role

claim: "Overall we currently have $981 million, almost a billion dollars in active development projects right here in the City of Richmond."
The military has spent $500 million enforcing the "Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell" policy regarding gays and lesbians in the military.
Congressman Robert Hurt has a plan to cut education by 40 percent.
qoute: Time for remedial math at DCCC

claim: Federal Reserve policies have led to a 69 percent rise in corn prices, 44 percent rise in wheat prices and 15 percent spike in sugar prices over the last year.
"The New START treaty was passed despite significant concerns among some people in the State and Defense Departments."
qoute: Big-wigs and brass backed this treaty

claim: The U.S. loses more on tax breaks than it collects in personal income taxes.
qoute: Changing the imbalance will cause pain

claim: "[Tailpipe emissions rules], if fully implemented with all the regulations that go with it, they will keep the temperature from rising nearly five one-hundredths of a degree Fahrenheit. By 2050."
George Allen voted for budgets that increased the national debt by $16,400 for every second he served in the U.S. Senate.
"It is estimated that every $100 million spent on construction generates 3,000 new jobs."
The governor has made a "commitment to billions of dollars in debt and new spending without any explanation of how he plans to pay that money back."
qoute: He voted for the missing plan...twice

claim: The health care reform law "offset[s] 6 years of benefits with 10 years of tax increases."
qoute: Some benefits as well as some taxes come early

claim: Virginia ranked 35th in job creation in 2009 under Gov. Tim Kaine, and moved up to third for 2010, while McDonnell has been in office.
qoute: Uses statistics that draw the starkest contrast

claim: Obama’s mid-term approval ratings are similar to other presidents who went on to re-election.
qoute: Mid-term marks below average but above Reagan's in first term

claim: New provisions of the health care law bar the use of flexible spending accounts and health savings accounts to pay for aspirin and other non-prescription health needs.
qoute: He's the Bayer of bad news

claim: "There hasn't really been a lot of net growth in the federal workforce when you compare it to say, 1990."
qoute: But use of government contractors has soared

claim: Proposed federal regulations would affect every street sign in the country
qoute: Not a capital idea, he says

claim: On whether the state should ramp up borrowing to build roads.
qoute: Voted for road bonds in 2007 but wasn't happy about it

claim: The tax-cut deal "adds more than $800 billion to the deficit over two years -- more than the cost of TARP and more than the cost of the Recovery Act" and about the same as health care reform.
qoute: He's right on two, close on the third

claim: "The Governor did not consult members of his own party before he released his [transportation] plan."
qoute: Many Republicans were in the loop

claim: On whether state employees should contribute to their pensions.
qoute: Says worsening conditions forced him to change

claim: Those who fail to buy health insurance under "Obamacare" face the threat of jail time.
qoute: No one is going to the Big House

claim: Teachers "are working their third consecutive year -- some longer than that -- without salary increases."
qoute: Most got raises for 2008-09 school year

claim: The Democrats' health care reform law is a "government takeover of health care."
qoute: Saying it doesn't make it true

claim: Sen. Jim Webb "persists on negating" Sen. Mark Warner’s votes
qoute: Webb and Warner in sync on 87 percent of votes

claim: The Bush-era tax cuts failed to increase employment and "work-force participation fell in 2001 and has never returned to the record level set in 2000."
qoute: Don't forget, there was a recession

claim: The national debt grew an estimated $15 billion last weekend.
qoute: The estimate, though accurate, varies from actual numbers

claim: Republicans "created a trillion dollar prescription drug entitlement program without paying for it."
qoute: He's close on the cost for the next decade

claim: "There’s talk in Congress now about basically confiscating your private 401(k) or IRA plan and rolling it into Social Security to strengthen Social Security."
qoute: No need to cash in your retirement savings

claim: "The tuitions in Virginia colleges...have doubled -- 100 percent -- in the last 10 years."
qoute: With three kids in college, he knows the facts.

claim: Letting the Bush tax cuts expire would raise taxes on small businesses.
Since the Fed was created in 1913, "the U.S. Dollar has lost 98% of its purchasing power."
qoute: A glaring omission: Wages have gone up dramatically since 1913.

claim: The health care reform law "reduces the deficit by nearly $1.2 trillion over the next two decades."
qoute: But his projections get dicey after 10 years

claim: The dollar "has fallen over 44% since Bernanke began pumping money into the system beginning back in 2002."
qoute: Dollar has fallen, but not that much

claim: "We’ve been able to create about 60,000 net new jobs" in Virginia since February.
qoute: His figure is close, but who deserves the credit for the new jobs?

claim: President Obama, Sen. Harry Reid and Rep. Nancy Pelosi passed a "$1.2 trillion stimulus bill."
qoute: Inflates stimulus cost by almost 50 percent

claim: $65 billion "would be added to the deficit if we keep the cuts for people on the highest incomes."
$65 million from ABC privatization will not pay for "even an overpass in Tysons Corner."
qoute: $65 million would cover it without major complications

claim: Has created 60,000 net new jobs since taking office.
qoute: His number is a tad high, but in the ballpark

claim: Republican plan to extend Bush tax cuts "would double deficit projections going forward for the next couple of decades."
qoute: Omits one fact: Democrats' plan would also balloon deficit

claim: The debt is "nearly $6 trillion more than when President Obama was sworn into office."
"The budget submitted by Obama will add more to the debt than the outstanding debt of the previous 43 presidents combined."
"If all of the [Bush-era] tax cuts expire on schedule, the budget will be close to being balanced in four years."
qoute: Ending the tax cuts wouldn’t even cut the deficit in half

claim: "Congressman Nye voted against a bill which would have defunded the $5-10 billion" the IRS needed to implement  health care legislation.
qoute: Nye's vote was on a minor procedural motion, not a bill

claim: Robert Hurt supported a bill that helped the uranium industry after taking contributions from the industry and because his father had a stake in it.
qoute: Hurt took $2,000 from mining officials but was cleared to vote on bill

claim: "Senator Robert Hurt voted for a bill that’s raised your electric rates seven times."
qoute: Deregulation was not a factor in raising rates

claim: "Congressman Perriello voted in lock step with Nancy Pelosi 90 percent of the time."
qoute: Perriello votes with Democrats, but not necessarily Pelosi

claim: "Rigell's car dealership made over $400,000 off the ‘Cash for Clunkers’ bailout."
qoute: Rigell's dealerships profited, but they didn't make $400,000

claim: "Mr. Hurt would re-open that darn (Medicare) doughnut hole."
qoute: Connecting the dots, Perriello seems right

claim: "Morgan Griffith fought for a plan that would have taken money away from our schools and given it to Northern Virginia schools instead."
qoute: No evidence Griffith fought for this

claim: Rick Boucher "helped write" the cap-and-trade bill
qoute: Yes, but to protect SW Virginia and coal industry

claim: In the past two years, Democrats have "spent more money than this country has spent in the last 200 years combined."
qoute: Wrong no matter how you slice it

claim: Says Robert Hurt "supports the tax loopholes that send American jobs overseas."
qoute: Hurt signed Taxpayer Protection Pledge, not a promise to close loopholes

claim: Says Glenn Nye voted "in lock step with Nancy Pelosi" 83 percent of the time.
Says Tom Perriello voted "to give tax breaks to foreign companies creating jobs in China."
qoute: No connection between manufacturing tax credit in stimulus, Chinese jobs

claim: Says he "voted no on the Wall Street bailouts."
qoute: He wasn't in Congress when TARP was approved.
